questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis?
questions.explanation:
Caucasian race is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis. The risk factors for bacterial vaginosis are: 706 
Sold by @itachibot • Oral sex • Vaginal douching • African race • Cigarette smoking • Sex during menses • Intrauterine device • Early age of sexual intercourse • New or multiple sexual partners • Sexual activity with other women Note: Bacterial vaginosis is not an infection. It most commonly affects young women. Although it 
is not a sexually transmitted disease, the chances of developing bacterial vaginosis seem to 
increase with the number of sexual partners that a woman has had.

questions.question:
Question 2: A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statements 
is false about this condition?

options.a: Gardnerella vaginalis is a causative agent
options.b: Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis
options.d: Oral metronidazole is given for treatment

questions.explanation:
Vaginal itching is not seen in bacterial vaginosis. It is a symptom of Trichomonas vaginitis. About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic women 
mostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, and 
dyspareunia. Option A: Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the absence of lactobacilli. This causes an increase in 
the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Myco- 
plasma□ hominis. Option B: Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. 3 out of 4 criteria are needed 
to make a positive diagnosis. Option D: Oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or oral clindamycin 300 mg twice 
daily for 7 days is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Treatment remains the same in 
pregnancy.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 30-year old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal 
discharge for the past 2 weeks. On examination, the discharge is adherent to the vaginal 
mucosa and has a fishy odour. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella. Patients with BV have profuse and yellowish vaginal discharge with a fishy odour. It is adherent 
to the vaginal mucosa. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are absent. On microscopy, clue 
cells are visible. Option A: In trichomonas vaginitis, the vaginal discharge is frothy, greenish-yellow and has an 
offensive smell. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are generally present. Option B: In candidal vaginitis, the discharge is thick and curdy white. 707 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: In chlamydial infection, the vaginal discharge is generally scanty.

questions.question:
Question 4: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not be 
seen? 699 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not 
an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora. A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic 
evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean 
background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These 
are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced number 
of Lactobacilli would also be seen. Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial 
vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of 
bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.question:
Question 5: Given below is the image of a smear prepared from the vaginal discharge of a patient. What is 
the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of clue cells on microscopy is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. A swab of the vaginal discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The 
microscopic evaluation of the smear is done on a gram stained smear. It would reveal a clean 
background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These 
are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced number 
of Lactobacilli would also be seen. Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial 
vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of 
bacteria. These are called clue cells. 708 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A woman comes to the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On 
examination, the discharge was profuse and had a fishy odour. Which of the following is the 
best criteria to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis which is confirmed by using Amsel’s 
criteria. 3 out of 4 of the following criteria are needed, to make a positive diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis: • A homogeneous, thin, greyish-white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls. • A vaginal pH > 4.5. • A positive whiff test - an amine like fishy odour is produced when a drop of 10% KOH is added 
to the sample of vaginal discharge. • The presence of >20% clue cells on saline wet mount. These are vaginal epithelial cells 
studded with adherent coccobacilli at the edge of the cell. Option A: Boer-Miesel's criteria is used for the prognostic evaluation of pelvic inflammatory 
disease. Option B: Light's criteria is used for determining the nature of the pleural fluid i.e., transudate or 
exudate, in the diagnosis of pleural effusion. Option D: Nugent's criteria can also be used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. However, it is not 
the best confirmatory method.

questions.question:
Question 7: In a patient with suspected bacterial vaginosis, Nugent's criteria is used to quantify the 
following bacteria except....
questions.explanation:
Nugent's criteria is used to evaluate three types of bacteria in a case of suspected bacterial 
vaginosis: Mobiluncus, Lactobacillus, and Gardnerella/Bacteroides. Bacteria are graded through 
gram stain of vaginal samples. They are each graded on a scale of 1+ to 4+ where: 709 
Sold by @itachibot • 1+ is < 1 cell per field • 2+ is 1-5 cells per field • 3+ is 6-30 cells per field • 4+ is >30 cells per field Lactobacillus and Bacteroides/Gardnerella are given scores between 0-4, but Mobiluncus is 
graded only from 0-2. The total scores are then calculated and interpreted as follows: • 0-3 - Normal • 4-6 - Intermediate bacterial count • 7-10 - Bacterial vaginosis

questions.question:
Question 8: A gynaecology resident noted a frothy, greenish, offensive-smelling vaginal discharge in a 
young lady. Whiff test was positive. Which organism is most likely implicated?
questions.explanation:
Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely organism implicated in this patient, causing trichomonas 
vaginitis. The whiff test can be positive in both Trichomonas and Gardnerella infections. However, greenish 
frothy discharge is seen in trichomonas vaginitis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient came to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal 
discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the 
appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism.
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely causative agent. Vaginal itching and foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge are seen in trichomonas vaginitis. The given image shows colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix, which is a characteristic finding of 
trichomoniasis. This is due to microscopic, punctate haemorrhages of the cervix. 710 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following organisms can be detected on a hanging drop preparation?
questions.explanation:
Trichomonas vaginalis can be detected on a hanging drop preparation. Trichomonas vaginalis is a 
protozoan with four anterior flagellae, and a fifth posterior flagellum responsible for motility. The image given below shows trophozoites of Trichomonas vaginalis with flagella.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 25-year-old woman came with complaints of greenish vaginal discharge. On saline 
microscopy, motile flagellated organisms were seen. What is the best treatment option for 
her?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trichomonas vaginitis and the best treatment option for 
her is oral metronidazole 2 g stat. The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis is: • An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or • A single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent 
infection. Treatment in pregnancy remains the same.

questions.question:
Question 12: A pregnant woman in her 7th week of gestation was diagnosed with trichomoniasis. Which of 
the following can be used to treat her condition?
questions.explanation:
Trichomonas vaginitis is treated with oral metronidazole in pregnant women. According to the current guidelines, metronidazole is now considered safe for treating 
trichomonas vaginitis in pregnancy as it has no teratogenic effect. The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis in pregnant women include: 711 
Sold by @itachibot • An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or a single oral dose of 
metronidazole 2 g • Usage of trichofuran suppositories • Vinegar douche to lower the vaginal pH • Betadine gel The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent 
infection.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents to your OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal 
discharge and intense itching. What is the likely causative agent for her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moniliasis and Candida albicans is the likely causative 
agent. The risk factors for moniliasis are: • Diabetes mellitus • Obesity • Multiple sexual partners • Immunosuppression • HIV • Pregnancy • Steroid therapy • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy • Oral contraceptive pills • Poor personal hygiene.

questions.question:
Question 14: 702 
Sold by @itachibot In an obese lady with complaints of vaginal discharge, a vaginal pH of 4.2 was detected. 
Which organism is implicated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The likely causative agent in the given clinical scenario is Candida which is known to flourish in 
an acidic environment. The pH of the vaginal discharge in candidal vaginitis is in the range of 
4-4.5.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing a candidal infection?
questions.explanation:
Hypertension does not increase the risk of developing a candidal infection. The risk factors for developing candidal vaginitis (moniliasis) are: • Diabetes mellitus 712 
Sold by @itachibot • Obesity • Multiple sexual partners • Immunosuppression • HIV • Pregnancy • Steroid therapy • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy • Oral contraceptive pills • Poor personal hygiene.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 32-year old woman presents to you with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching. On 
examination, you note a curdy white discharge and an inflamed vagina. What is the best 
treatment for her?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of candidal vaginitis. A single dose of fluconazole 150 
mg is the best treatment for treating candidal vaginitis. Intravaginal antifungal 
(imidazole/miconazole/clotrimazole) vaginal pessaries or creams can also be used for 3–6 days.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not a primary site for gonococcal infection?
questions.explanation:
Ectocervix and vagina are lined by squamous epithelium which is resistant to gonococcal 
infection. The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional 
epithelium. Hence, gonococcus usually affects the following structures: • Endocervix • Urethra 713 
Sold by @itachibot • Skene’s glands • Bartholin's glands.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following presentations is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea?
questions.explanation: Haematuria is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea. Gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is: • Excessive vaginal discharge associated with pruritus and inflammation • Acute unilateral pain and swelling over labia due to the involvement of Bartholin’s gland • Intermenstrual bleeding Non-gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is: • Pharyngeal infection • Dysuria • Rectal discomfort due to associated proctitis.

questions.question: Question 19: What is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia trachomatis. The causes of non-gonococcal urethritis are: • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common) • Ureaplasma urealyticum • Adenovirus • Haemophillus vaginalis • Mycoplasma genitalium • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.question:
Question 20: A 35-year-old sex worker was suspected to have chlamydial cervicitis. What is the most 
sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis of chlamydial cervicitis is the polymerase 
chain reaction (PCR). It is fast, highly sensitive and specific (96%).

questions.question:
Question 21: A 25-year-old woman had complaints of lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. On 
microscopy, the following finding was present. What is the selective culture media used to 
isolate the causative organism? 704 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Culture on bilayer human blood agar

questions.explanation:
714 
Sold by @itachibot Chlamydia trachomatis is the most likely causative organism. This is suggested by the presence of 
characteristic iodine-stained inclusion bodies in the McCoy cell culture of the patient's 
endocervical sample. Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show 
abundant leucocytes but no organisms. The nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is currently done for the diagnosis of 
lymphogranuloma venereum.

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient with complaints of vaginal discharge was evaluated. On an endocervical biopsy, 
chlamydia was detected. How will you treat this patient?
questions.explanation:
A single dose of 1 g of azithromycin is given and contact tracing is done to treat a patient 
diagnosed with a chlamydial infection. Treatment of chlamydial infection: • Azithromycin 1 g single dose (or) • Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID × 7 days (or) • Ofloxacin 200 mg orally BID × 7 days (or) • Erythromycin 500 mg orally BID × 7 days Contact tracing should always be done. The sexual partner should also be treated with the same 
regimen.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 25-year-old lady complains of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning. 
What is the route of administration of the first non-azole drug approved to treat this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical history of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning are suggestive 
of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The first and the only non-azole antifungal approved for the treatment 
of vulvovaginal candidiasis is Ibrexafungerp. The route of administration of this drug is oral. Ibrexafungerp is a triterpenoid antifungal agent that acts by inhibiting glucan synthase. Glucan 
synthase is an enzyme involved in the formation of 1,3-beta-D-glucan which is an essential 
component of the fungal cell wall. The recommended dosage is 600 mg orally as 2 divided doses 12 hrs apart. Contraindications 
include pregnancy and hypersensitivity to ibrexafungerp. The most frequent adverse reactions are 
diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, dizziness, and vomiting. 715 
Sold by @itachibot Vulval Infections
